title: "What do negative rates mean for investors?"
text:
The Nuveen article seems quite conservative in stating what investors should do.

But then, we have this paragraph:

Does it make sense for investors to own negative-yielding bonds?

In many cases, yes, especially since these bonds have already contributed to returns in 2019. Consider that the Bloomberg Barclays Germany Treasury Bond Index began the year with a -0.1% yield, but has returned over 6% in euros year to date through August 12. Negative yielding bonds may not be attractive for most individual investors if held to maturity, but their prices may still rise over shorter periods, giving them value if used judiciously in diversified portfolios.

I don't get it. Bonds are not growth investments; they are contractual instruments. At the end maturity date, you get back par, barring default. So with a $1000 face bond, you get back $1000 in principal at the end. However, to have a negative interest rate bond (most do not have actual negative coupons) the bond must be selling above par. Like $1075 per bond. So if held to maturity, you lose...

The article paragraph says above " Negative yielding bonds may not be attractive for most individual investors if held to maturity, but their prices may still rise over shorter periods, giving them value if used judiciously in diversified portfolios." So Nuveen is saying if used judiciously. What does this mean other than short term speculation for a further capital gain. And it means the investor must SELL to realize any gain, or else you lose it when the bond matures . I doubt many retirees want to take this risk, or even want to do any such trading.
